questions.question_text: Which Talos reputation center allows for tracking the reputation of IP addresses for email and web traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct
The switch forwards ARP packets that it receives on a trusted interface, but does not check them. 
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/general/Test/dwerblo/broken_guide/dynarp.html

DAI determines the validity of an ARP packet based on valid IP-to-MAC address bindings stored in a trusted database, the DHCP snooping binding database. This database is built by DHCP snooping if DHCP snooping is enabled on the VLANs and on the switch. If the ARP packet is received on a trusted interface, the switch forwards the packet without any checks. On untrusted interfaces, the switch forwards the packet only if it is valid.
so B is correct!!!

B is correct ...DAI determines the validity of an ARP packet based on valid IP-to-MAC address bindings stored in a trusted database, the DHCP snooping binding database. This database is built by DHCP snooping if DHCP snooping is enabled on the VLANs and on the switch. If the ARP packet is received on a trusted interface, the switch forwards the packet without any checks. On untrusted interfaces, the switch forwards the packet only if it is valid.

A

Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) is a security feature that helps protect against ARP spoofing attacks by validating ARP packets against an IP-to-MAC address binding table. When a switch receives a spoofed ARP response on a trusted interface, it will check the IP-to-MAC address binding table to see if the source IP address and source MAC address match. If they do not match, the switch will drop the packet as it is determined to be a spoofed packet. This helps to protect the network from man-in-the-middle attacks and other ARP spoofing-based attacks.

comments.content: sorry,the answer should be B..as per below Packets arriving on trusted interfaces bypass all DAI validation checks and are forwarded without validation by the switch

questions.question_text: A switch with Dynamic ARP Inspection enabled has received a spoofed ARP response on a trusted interface. How does the switch behave in this situation?

choices.B: It forwards the packet without validation.
choices.A: It drops the packet after validation by using the IP & MAC Binding Table.
choices.D: It drops the packet without validation.
choices.C: It forwards the packet after validation by using the IP & MAC Binding Table.

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios-xml/ios/netflow/configuration/15-2s/cfg-nflow-top-talk.html#GUID-824723EE-2551-4D64-9E0B-F5DF065C83B9

The given answer is correct. Steps are clearly outlined in the guide.

comments.content:
In this area which mean on the answer put " configure the ip flow command on an interface" on the last step..

if you read the guide the number 3 say "" (Required) Specifies the interface on which you want to enable NetFlow and enters interface configuration mode. ""

so the sequence for this question is 

Configure ip routing and enable Cisco Express Forwarding: Step 1
- Configure the ip flow command on an interface: Step 2 --- on the guide it no 3
- Configure the ip flow-top-talkers command: Step 3
- Specify the maximum number of top talkers: Step 4
- Set the top-talkers sorting criterion: Step 5

discussion.content:
Actually, In the beggining i was thining to activate flow collection on interface right after CEF activation, but later i realised that seems more correct to configure the ip flow command on an inteface at the END, as this will activate the flow statistics collection. 
Doesn't makes a lot of sense to have a flow collection running and at the same time to change the top-talkers config (means the data that collected).

Therefore, the answer seems 100% correct to me.

I could prefer:

Configure ip routing and enable Cisco Express Forwarding: Step 1
Configure the ip flow command on an interface: Step 2
Configure the ip flow-top-talkers command: Step 3
Specify the maximum number of top talkers: Step 4
Set the top-talkers sorting criterion: Step 5

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/netflow/configuration/15-mt/nf-15-mt-book/cfg-nflow-top-talk.html

Question doesn't provide enough context. I'd hope this would be correct enough, although step 1 and step 5 could theoretcially have been done as 1 and 2, or 4 and 5:

1) Configure ip routing and enable Cisco Express Forwarding
2) Configure the ip flow-top-talkers command
3) Specify the maximum number of top talkers
4) Set the top-talkers sorting criterion
5) Configure the ip flow command on an interface

https://www.kareemccie.com/2016/08/how-to-configure-netflow-top-talkers-on.html

Configure ip routing and enable Cisco Express Forwarding: Step 1
- Configure the ip flow command on an interface: Step 2
- Configure the ip flow-top-talkers command: Step 3
- Specify the maximum number of top talkers: Step 4
- Set the top-talkers sorting criterion: Step 5
This looks correct.
